function fun(arr, q, n, m) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(n), q, n, m
    integer :: res, i, j, md

    res = 1
    i = 1
    j = n
    do while (i <= j)
        md = i + (j - i)/2  ! same as (i +j)/2 using integer division
        if (arr(md) == q) then
            res = md
            return
        else if (arr(md) > q) then
            res = md
            j = md - 1
        else
            i = md + 1
        end if
    end do
end function

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, m, i, x
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:), q(:)
    integer :: fun

    !
segments.label: high_level_plan

segments.text:
Read n
    read(*,*) n
    allocate(arr(n))
    read(*,*) arr(1) do i = 2, n
        read(*,*) x
        arr(i) = arr(i-1) + x
    end do

    !
segments.label: code_analysis

segments.text:
Read m and queries
    read(*,*) m
    allocate(q(m)) do i = 1, m
        read(*,*) q(i)
    end do

    ! Process queries
    do i = 1, m
        write(*,*) fun(arr, q(i), n, m)
    end do

    deallocate(arr, q)
end program main

function fun(arr, q, n, m) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(n), q, n, m
    integer :: res, i, j, md

    res = 1
    i = 1
    j = n
    do while (i <= j)
        md = i + (j - i)/2 if (arr(md) == q) then
            res = md
            return
        else if (arr(md) > q) then
            res = md
            j = md - 1
        else
            i = md + 1
        end if
    end do
end function fun

segments.text:
Alternatively, in Fortran, the 'contains' keyword can be used to include the function within the main program's scope, which makes the interface known. So modifying the code:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, m, i, x
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:), q(:)

    read(*,*) n
    allocate(arr(n)) read(*,*) arr(1) do i = 2, n
        read(*,*) x
        arr(i) = arr(i-1) + x
    end do

    read(*,*) m
    allocate(q(m)) do i = 1, m
        read(*,*) q(i)
    end do

    do i = 1, m
        write(*,*) binary_search(arr, q(i), n)
    end do

    deallocate(arr, q)
contains
    integer function binary_search(arr, q, n)
        integer, intent(in) :: arr(n), q, n
        integer :: low, high, mid

        low = 1
        high = n
        binary_search = n  ! Default to the last element if all are less than q

        do while (low <= high)
            mid = (low + high) / 2
            if (arr(mid) == q) then
                binary_search = mid
                return
            else if (arr(mid) > q) then
                binary_search = mid
                high = mid - 1
            else
                low = mid + 1
            end if
        end do
    end function binary_search
end program main

Wait, this way, the function is inside the main program, and the interface is known.

original_reasoning:
Okay, I need to translate this Java code into Fortran. Let's start by understanding what the Java code does. 

The program reads an array of integers where each element is the cumulative sum of the previous elements. Then, for each query, it finds the smallest index where the cumulative sum is greater than or equal to the query value using a binary search.

First, let me think about the structure of Fortran code. Fortran uses subroutines and functions, and I'll need to handle input/output similarly. 

In the Java code, the main method reads 'n' and then reads 'n' integers into an array, where each element is the sum of the previous. So in Fortran, I'll read 'n', then read the first element. Then for each subsequent element, I read a value and add it to the previous sum. That part seems straightforward.

Next, the Java code reads 'm' queries. Each query is processed by the 'fun' function, which is a binary search. The function returns the index where the cumulative sum meets the condition, and then they print that index plus one (since Java uses 0-based indices and the problem might expect 1-based).

In Fortran, arrays are 1-based by default, but the original Java code uses 0-based. So I need to adjust indices accordingly. function fun(arr, q, n, m) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(n), q, n, m
    integer :: res, i, j, md

    res = 1
    i = 1
    j = n
    do while (i <= j)
        md = i + (j - i)/2  ! same as (i +j)/2 using integer division
        if (arr(md) == q) then
            res = md
            return
        else if (arr(md) > q) then
            res = md
            j = md - 1
        else
            i = md + 1
        end if
    end do
end function

Now, the main program.

In Fortran, we need to read the inputs. Let's outline the steps.

Read n.

Read the first element as arr(1).

Then for i from 2 to n, read x, and set arr(i) = arr(i-1)+x.

Then read m.

Read m elements into q array.

For each q element, call fun and print the result.

But in Fortran, the function needs to be declared. Also, Fortran requires explicit interfaces for functions, but in a simple program, perhaps we can avoid that.

But for code correctness, perhaps using a function with an explicit interface is better. But for simplicity, let's proceed.

So the Fortran code structure would be:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, m, i, x
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:), q(:)
    integer :: fun

    ! Read n
    read(*,*) n
    allocate(arr(n))
    read(*,*) arr(1)
    do i = 2, n
        read(*,*) x
        arr(i) = arr(i-1) + x
    end do

    ! Read m and queries
    read(*,*) m
    allocate(q(m))
    do i = 1, m
        read(*,*) q(i)
    end do

    ! Process queries
    do i = 1, m
        write(*,*) fun(arr, q(i), n, m)
    end do

    deallocate(arr, q)
end program main

function fun(arr, q, n, m) result(res)
    integer, intent(in) :: arr(n), q, n, m
    integer :: res, i, j, md

    res = 1
    i = 1
    j = n
    do while (i <= j)
        md = i + (j - i)/2
        if (arr(md) == q) then
            res = md
            return
        else if (arr(md) > q) then
            res = md
            j = md - 1
        else
            i = md + 1
        end if
    end do
end function fun

But wait, in Fortran, integer division is done with /, but when using (j -i)/2, since j and i are integers, j-i is integer. So (j -i)/2 is integer division.

But the original Java code uses md = i + (j -i)/2 which is equivalent to (i + j)/2. So in Fortran, we can compute md as (i + j)/2.

But since Fortran uses integer division, (i + j) must be even. For example, i=3, j=4: (3+4)/2=3.5 →3 in integer division.

So the code can be written as md = (i + j)/2.

But when the function is defined after the main program, and the main program uses implicit none, then the compiler may not know the function's interface. So this can cause errors. Therefore, to avoid this, the function should be placed before the main program, or an interface block should be provided.

Alternatively, in Fortran, the 'contains' keyword can be used to include the function within the main program's scope, which makes the interface known.

So modifying the code:

program main
    implicit none
    integer :: n, m, i, x
    integer, allocatable :: arr(:), q(:)

    read(*,*) n
    allocate(arr(n))
    read(*,*) arr(1)
    do i = 2, n
        read(*,*) x
        arr(i) = arr(i-1) + x
    end do

    read(*,*) m
    allocate(q(m))
    do i = 1, m
        read(*,*) q(i)
    end do

    do i = 1, m
        write(*,*) binary_search(arr, q(i), n)
    end do

    deallocate(arr, q)
contains
    integer function binary_search(arr, q, n)
        integer, intent(in) :: arr(n), q, n
        integer :: low, high, mid

        low = 1
        high = n
        binary_search = n  ! Default to the last element if all are less than q

        do while (low <= high)
            mid = (low + high) / 2
            if (arr(mid) == q) then
                binary_search = mid
                return
            else if (arr(mid) > q) then
                binary_search = mid
                high = mid - 1
            else
                low = mid + 1
            end if
        end do
    end function binary_search
end program main
